author: jon
msg: Okay, I've got it - four bugs!
1) readObject/writeObject in StandardSession don't serialize
thisAccessedTime, so it ends up as 0 after deserialization - the net
result of which is the session expires rather shortly after :-(
2) My patch for SessionSerializer foolishly assumes that the request
triggering the reload has a session itself, so when the session expires
SessionSerializer ends up stuffing an invalid session in the current
request (hence the isValid failure)
3) Similar-ish to (1) readObject in StandardSession doesn't account
for the fact that the StringManger field 'sm' will start off as null -
the normal initializer doesn't run, hence the NPE when the session is
invalid. I've fixed this by setting sm in readObject - is there any
reason not to make it static?
4) I don't think this one was actually involved in the scenario Jon
described, but I also noticed that the backpointer to StandardManager in
the sessions doesn't get set after deserialization either.
The patch below fixes these issues.
Sean Legassick
sean@somacity.com

author: craigmcc
msg: Modify DefaultServlet to ask for the absolute path to the document root,
rather than the document root itself.
I *think* this fixes the problem of wanting to set the document root
as a relative path starting with "../", without allowing any security
issues.  Please help me validate this belief.

author: craigmcc
msg: Use java.security.SecureRandom, instead of java.util.Random, to generate
the random part of session identifiers.  This costs you a little bit of
startup time on the very first session identifier generated, but creates
more cryptographically secure session identifiers than before.
